id_and_class.theory_title: Feinberg and Mallatt’s Ancient Origins of Consciousness
id_and_class.summary: This theory proposes that phenomenal consciousness emerged much earlier in evolutionary history than often assumed, coinciding with the great Cambrian explosion 520–560 million years ago. It argues that the development of the first complex brains converted simple reflexive behaviors into a unified inner world of subjective experiences, meaning all vertebrates, and possibly some invertebrates, are conscious.
id_and_class.core_identity_tagline: Consciousness emerged with the first complex brains

conceptual_ground.explanatory_identity_claim: Consciousness is identified as a unified inner world of subjective experiences arising from specific biological and neurobiological features established early in vertebrate evolution.
conceptual_ground.mind_body_relationship: Mind (consciousness) is the emergent product of complex biological brain structures.
conceptual_ground.emergence_type: Weak Emergence (Justification: As a Materialist theory of consciousness based on evolutionary neurobiology, consciousness is assumed to be fully reducible, in principle, to its physical basis upon sufficient scientific advancement.)
conceptual_ground.subjectivity_and_intentionality: Subjectivity is the 'unified inner world of subjective experiences' created by the complex brain structure. Intentionality is a resulting function that evolved from simple reflexive behaviors.
conceptual_ground.qualia_account: Qualia (subjective experiences) are accounted for as the output of specific biological and neurobiological features that arose with the first complex brains.
conceptual_ground.ontological_commitments: Complex brains, specific biological and neurobiological features, neural patterns.
conceptual_ground.epistemic_access: Accessed through investigating and comparing biological and neurobiological features of contemporary species against the fossil record (third-person evidence).
conceptual_ground.constituents_and_structure: Biological and neurobiological features of complex brains, particularly those that originated during the Cambrian explosion.

mechanism_and_dynamics.distinctive_mechanism_or_principle: The evolutionary emergence of complex brains (520–560 million years ago) endowed with a comprehensive set of biological and neurobiological features sufficient to transition from simple reflexes to unified subjective experience.
mechanism_and_dynamics.dynamics_of_emergence: Dynamic process tied to phylogenetic history; consciousness arose incrementally as simple reflexive behaviors evolved into a unified inner world.
mechanism_and_dynamics.location_and_distribution: Located in the nervous systems of all vertebrates and potentially some complex invertebrates (arthropods and cephalopods).
mechanism_and_dynamics.causation_and_functional_role: Consciousness functions as the evolutionary result of the brain creating experience from simple behaviors; its ultimate role is adaptive, enhancing survival capabilities.
mechanism_and_dynamics.integration_or_binding: Integration is achieved by the complex brains creating a 'unified inner world' of experience.
mechanism_and_dynamics.information_flow_or_representation: Information processing and representation are assumed to be organized by the evolved complex brain structure to create subjective experience.
mechanism_and_dynamics.evolutionary_account: Consciousness evolved significantly earlier (520–560 million years ago) than standard models suggest, originating in conjunction with the complex brains of the Cambrian explosion.
core_claims_and_evidence: Consciousness arose during the Cambrian explosion (520–560 million years ago).
All vertebrates are and have always been conscious.
The complexity of these ancient brains converted simple reflexes into a unified inner world of subjective experience.

empirics_and_critiques.testability_status: Empirically testable through ongoing comparative study of neurobiological features across divergent species.
empirics_and_critiques.known_empirical_interventions_or_tests: Comparative neurobiological analysis of existing vertebrates and invertebrates against evolutionary timescales and anatomical criteria.
empirics_and_critiques.criticisms_and_tensions: The theory is noted to challenge the standard model of consciousness evolution. Its marketing claim of solving the 'hard problem' is presented as less definitive by the authors themselves.
empirics_and_critiques.open_questions_and_limitations: It is unclear how the theory provides an original solution to the 'hard problem' of phenomenal experience.
empirics_and_critiques.ontological_coherence: Coherent with a fundamental materialist and evolutionary ontology, locating consciousness firmly within biological science.

AI_consciousness.rationale: As a Materialism Theory, there is no in-principle prohibition against artificially reproducing the complex physical structure necessary for consciousness to emerge.

survival_beyond_death.rationale: Consciousness is understood as a product of biological neural processes (complex brains) which cease upon biological death.

meaning_and_purpose.rationale: As consciousness is an evolved biological mechanism, it offers no ultimate cosmic meaning or purpose beyond adaptive function and human self-creation.

virtual_immortality.rationale: Since consciousness is tied entirely to physical features (evolved complex brain structure), duplication of those features in a new medium should preserve the mental self, making virtual immortality attainable.

sources_and_references.title_with_names: The Ancient Origins of Consciousness: How the Brain Created Experience, Todd Feinberg and Jon Mallatt
